title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: In the distance, northwestward,  rose the mountains of Mull — a long line of sable bastions and parapets, distinct  and huge, against a streak of yellow light.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: It is formed like the cross of St. Martin, in front of the cathedral ruin, — except that the ends of the transverse beam are not grooved to the nimbus, as they are in St. Martin's, evidently  incomplete, — and it is made of red granite taken from the quarry in Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: A wreath of mist was on Ben More, but the peak of that mountain stood clearly forth above it, and, scattered here and there among the glistening  red rocks of Mull, the little cottages seemed more than ever the abodes of predestinate  and unassailable peace.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: When half way across the Strait of Iona the voyager may see weird Staffa in one direction, the savage Torran Rocks in another, and the Morven heights just peeping over Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Nowhere have I found more primitive manners  than in Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: I made my way into Mull, as far as the Parish of Icolmkill extends, its eastern boundary being marked by a tiny brook, the burnie of Scottish song, which ripples beneath the road, not far eastward of Loch Porlie.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: The landing  upon Mull was accomplished by difficult scrambling over a mass of jagged rocks, and presently I came to a neat road, that winds away across the great island, eastward and north, toward the villages of Kintra and Bunessan.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Eastward the crags of Mull grow dark, while high above them, girdling

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Far off, in austere Mull, the rays of the sun, falling from behind a great cloud, light up the red, barren rocks, and make them, for a moment, great masses of ruby and diamond.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Eastward green Inchkenneth smiled upon sable TJlva and the jagged, ruddy coast of Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Upon both shores of the spacious Sound of Mull I saw the many ruined castles that Scott has immortalised,

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: On Mull the mountain shapes were dark and stately, and the green hills of Morven — less impressive, however, than when they are half hidden  by streamers of drifting mist — stood forth, bold and splendid, in the gray light of an autumn morning.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: The clannish feeling,  the native language, and the primitive customs of the Highlander have not, indeed, been extinguished ; but they survive only in remote and isolated places — such as Morven, Iona, Mull, and Colonsay, and such as the weird Pass of Glencoe.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Far to the eastward were visible the gigantic double peaks of Ben Cruachan, and not alone those proud, imperial heights, but the spires and ridges of all the mountain chains around Glen Creran, Glen Etive, Glen Kinglas, and Glen Strae ; while in the west, defined with wonderful sharpness of outline, rose the frowning bastions of Morven,  and, more southerly, the black, precipitous  mountains of Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Far off, in the north and west, ridge beyond ridge, extend the dark and frowning mountains of Morven and of Mull.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: In front were visible the lighthouse on the southern arm of Lismore,  the lady rock, — a dark speck in the glassy water, whence the Campbells rescued  Fair Ellen of Lorn, — the ruins of Duart Castle, in Mull, and of Ardtornish, in Morven, the ancient fortress of the Lord of the Isles.

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Gazing from a headland on the west coast of Kerrera, I saw the dark mountains of Mull and Morven, clear-cut against the heavens, — vast masses of rock and verdure, softly relieved by spots of light, and calm as if no gale had ever swept their summits, nor darkness, tempest, and
